Article 5
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act;provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.
t2: Acceptance made by a minor that received an offer of gifts without burden without getting consent from his/her statutory agent may not be rescinded.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Whether the acceptance of a gift offer made to a minor without the consent of their legal representative is voidable.

Rule: According to Article 5(1) of the law, a minor must obtain the consent of their legal representative to perform a juridical act. However, this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation. Article 5(2) further states that a juridical act in contravention of the provisions of paragraph (1) is voidable. Article 5(3) allows a minor to dispose of property if their legal representative has permitted them to do so for a specific purpose or without specifying a purpose.

Application: In the given premise, the hypothesis states that a minor accepted an offer of gifts without getting consent from their legal representative. Since accepting the offer constitutes a juridical act, it should have been done with the consent of the legal representative as per Article 5(1). However, the article also states that this rule does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation. If the offer of gifts was without any burden, it could be considered as a right or a release from an obligation, and hence the consent of the legal representative may not be required. However, this exemption is not explicitly mentioned in the hypothesis, and it is unclear whether the offer was made without any burden.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis, it is not possible to determine whether the hypothesis is true or false without further information on the details of the gift offer. If the offer was without any burden, the acceptance made by the minor without the consent of the legal representative may not be rescinded. However, if the offer was not without any burden, then the acceptance would be voidable and could be rescinded.

Article 6
(1) A minor who is permitted to conduct one or multiple types of business has the same capacity to act as an adult as far as that business is concerned.
(2) In a case as referred to in the preceding paragraph, if there are grounds that make the minor unable to sustain that business, the legal representative may revoke or limit the permission therefor in accordance with the provisions of Part IV (Relatives).
t2: If a minor, after getting permission for carrying a business from his/her statutory agent, performs an act unrelated to the business without getting consent of the statutory agent, that act may not be rescinded.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Whether an act performed by a minor, unrelated to the business for which they were granted permission, without the consent of their legal representative, can be rescinded.

Rule: Article 6(1) states that a minor who is permitted to conduct one or multiple types of business has the same capacity to act as an adult as far as that business is concerned. However, Article 6(2) allows the legal representative to revoke or limit the permission granted to a minor to conduct a business if there are grounds that make the minor unable to sustain that business.

Application: In the given premise, the hypothesis states that a minor who has permission to conduct a business from their legal representative performs an act unrelated to the business without their consent. It is not clear whether the act was performed within the scope of the permission granted to the minor or not. If the act was performed within the scope of the business permission granted to the minor, then the minor would have the same capacity to act as an adult, and the consent of the legal representative may not be required. However, if the act was outside the scope of the permission granted, then it would be considered a juridical act and would require the consent of the legal representative. 

Conclusion: Based on the analysis, it is not possible to determine whether the hypothesis is true or false without further information on the details of the business permission granted and the nature of the act performed. If the act was within the scope of the business permission granted, the minor may not need the consent of the legal representative, and the act may not be rescinded. However, if the act was outside the scope of the permission granted, the consent of the legal representative would be required, and the act could be rescinded.

t2: If a person under curatorship performs, without getting the consent, an act that requires  getting consent from his/her curator, the curator may ratify that act, but may not rescind that act.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Whether a curator can ratify but not rescind an act performed by a person under curatorship without obtaining the necessary consent.

Rule: According to Article 13(1), a person under curatorship must obtain the consent of their curator for certain acts, which includes giving a gift, reaching a settlement, or entering into an arbitration agreement, among others. If the person under curatorship performs any act without obtaining the required consent, the act is voidable, as per Article 13(4). However, Article 122 states that a voidable act may not be rescinded after it has been ratified, and Article 120(1) specifies that only the person with qualified legal capacity, their agent or successor, or a person authorized to give consent, can rescind an act that is voidable on the grounds of qualified legal capacity.

Application: In the given premise, the hypothesis states that if a person under curatorship performs an act without obtaining the required consent from their curator, the curator may ratify the act but may not rescind it. According to the rules stated in Article 13 and Article 122, a voidable act can be ratified, and once ratified, it cannot be rescinded. However, the curator is not authorized to rescind an act that is voidable due to a lack of qualified legal capacity, as per Article 120(1). Therefore, if the act was voidable due to the lack of required consent, the curator may ratify it, but they cannot rescind it.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis, the hypothesis is true. According to the rules stated in Article 13, Article 120, and Article 122, if a person under curatorship performs an act without obtaining the required consent from their curator, the act is voidable, and the curator cannot rescind it. However, the curator may ratify the act, and once ratified, it cannot be rescinded.

Article 189
(1) A possessor in good faith acquires fruits derived from the thing under possession.
(2) If a possessor in good faith is defeated in an action on the title that legally supports the possession, that possessor is deemed to be a possessor in bad faith as from the time when the action is filed.
Article 190
(1) A possessor in bad faith has the obligation to return fruits, and reimburse the price of fruits that the possessor has already consumed, damaged due to negligence, or failed to collect.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph apply mutatis mutandis to a person who takes possession of a thing through assault or duress or through concealment.
t2: A possessor in good faith shall acquire fruits derived from  Thing in his/her possession , but a person in possession Thing through duress shall be obliged to return fruits, and if the fruits have already been consumed, he/she shall be obliged  to reimburse the cost of the fruits.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Whether a possessor in good faith and a person in possession of a thing through duress have different obligations with respect to fruits derived from the thing.

Rule: Article 189(1) states that a possessor in good faith acquires fruits derived from the thing under possession. Article 189(2) provides that if a possessor in good faith is defeated in an action on the title that legally supports the possession, they will be deemed to be a possessor in bad faith from the time the action is filed. Article 190(1) provides that a possessor in bad faith has the obligation to return fruits, and reimburse the price of fruits that they have already consumed, damaged due to negligence, or failed to collect. Article 190(2) extends the provisions of Article 190(1) to a person who takes possession of a thing through assault, duress, or concealment.

Application: The hypothesis states that a possessor in good faith shall acquire fruits derived from the thing under their possession, while a person in possession of a thing through duress shall be obliged to return fruits and reimburse the cost of fruits that have already been consumed. Based on the rules stated in Articles 189 and 190, a possessor in good faith has the right to acquire fruits derived from the thing under their possession. On the other hand, a person who takes possession of a thing through duress has the same obligations as a possessor in bad faith. Therefore, a person in possession of a thing through duress would be obliged to return fruits and reimburse the cost of fruits that have already been consumed or damaged due to negligence, as per Article 190(1). 

Conclusion: Based on the analysis, the hypothesis is partially true. A possessor in good faith acquires fruits derived from the thing under their possession, while a person in possession of a thing through duress would be obliged to return fruits and reimburse the cost of fruits that have already been consumed or damaged due to negligence, as per Article 190(1).

Article 89
(1) The ownership of natural fruits is acquired by the person entitled to obtain them when they are separated from the original thing.
(2) A person acquires civil fruits in proportion to the duration of the right to obtain them, as calculated on a prorated, daily basis.
t2: If person A donates a house that he/she is renting to person C with a provision for the payment of rent at the end of every month to person B midway through the month, if there is a special agreement between person A and person B, the rent for the month will be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of the days.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Whether the rent for a house, donated by person A to person C with a provision for payment of rent to person B at the end of every month, will be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of days, if person A donates the house midway through the month.

Rule: According to Article 89(2), a person acquires civil fruits in proportion to the duration of the right to obtain them, as calculated on a prorated, daily basis. This means that the person entitled to civil fruits is entitled to them in proportion to the number of days that they have the right to obtain them.

Application: The hypothesis states that if person A donates a house that he/she is renting to person C with a provision for payment of rent at the end of every month to person B midway through the month, if there is a special agreement between person A and person B, the rent for the month will be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of days. As per the rule in Article 89(2), the person entitled to civil fruits, in this case, person B, is entitled to them in proportion to the number of days that they have the right to obtain them. Therefore, if there is a special agreement between person A and person B, the rent for the month can be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of days that each party has the right to obtain them.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis, the hypothesis is true. If person A donates a house that he/she is renting to person C with a provision for payment of rent at the end of every month to person B midway through the month, the rent for the month can be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of days, provided that there is a special agreement between them, as per the rule in Article 89(2).
